Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer with Solid State Capabilities to Serve the Region Surrounding Memphis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Theodore Burkey from the University of Memphis (UM) and colleagues Tomoko Fujiwara, Daniel Baker and Xuan Zhao will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer with solid state capabilities. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance. The instrument also allows study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The cryogenic probe provides a significant increase in sensitivity relative to standard NMR probes. The results from these NMR studies have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate and graduate students. Seven faculty members at UM serve as research project leaders comprising the primary user team. The NMR increases productivity, enables new areas of investigation, and enhances UM as a regional resource for industry. Since the NMR solids capability is not available in the region it has become a resource for regional research-intensive institutions including the University of Mississippi. The automatic sample changer along with internet connectivity allows real experimental results to be integrated in lab curricula for UM and local four-year colleges.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying cancer phototherapy using multifunctional nanocomplexes; (b) studying chemical modification of smart chitosan implants; (c) analyzing chain exchange kinetics and mechanism of tri-block copolymer micelles during sol-to-gel transitions; (d) investigating functional nanoporous membranes; (e) designing of metal complexes for catalytic splitting of water; (f) developing sub-picosecond photoresponsive organometallics; (g) investigating halogen bond-driven assemblies in pi-conjugated oligomers for materials applications; (h) designing sphingosine kinase and diacylglycerol kinase assays; and (i) studying autotaxin inhibitor optimization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over a three year period (08/01/2015-07/31/2018) a Major Research Instrumentation Award enabled the purchase, installation, and operation a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer with a multinuclear probe, a solid-state probe, and an automated 64 sample changer. This 400 MHz spectrometer replaces a spectrometer operated 23 years at field where recent hardware failure interrupted research and teaching on a weekly basis.  Beyond the three-year MRI award period, the university will support the operation of the new spectrometer with an expected service lifetime of 15-20 years.

Installation of the new spectrometer was completed during year 1. During years 2 and 3 the spectrometer provided hands on training and data acquisition for research by 53 users: 6 faculty, 5 postdoctoral fellows, 21 graduate students, 17 undergraduates, and 3 corporate users. Corporate use of the spectrometer was scheduled when it did not interfere with academic use. Under-represented groups in science were 11% African American, 2% Hispanic, and 42% female. The new spectrometer was critical in hiring three new faculty in organic and organometallic chemistry, one hire was from two underrepresented groups in chemistry (female and African American). Investigators from other academic institutions used the spectrometer: the Jurss group at the University of Mississippi and Yahia Hamada at Lemoyne Owens College (an HBCU).

The 400 MHz NMR spectrometer enable research in several laboratories. (1) Two compounds were prepared for the measurement of intracellular activation involving G protein coupled receptors which are believed to be the ultimate targets of up to half of all drugs.  (2) Several compounds were synthesized and examined as autotaxin inhibitors in collaboration with the University of Tennessee Health Science Center.  Autotaxin is reported to be involved in tumor development. (3) Antibiotic analogs to bacterial signaling factors were prepared in collaboration with the Department of Biomedical Engineering. (4) The extent of deacetylation of a chitosan material was determined for studies to develop guided tissue regeneration membranes for tissue healing. (5) The chemical degradation and structure of new nanoporous membranes were examined for improved ion conductivity and membrane stability in the development of new battery technology. (6) Hydrogels containing DNA were found to release DNA with increasing temperature in studies for DNA delivery. (7) Transition metal complexes were prepared where the metal has a vacant site that is spatially encumbered preventing binding by bases and show evidence of small molecule activation. (8) Iridium and rhodium complexes containing aluminum ligands were prepared to understand how aluminum can be used to prepare new catalysts. (9) Manganese and chromium complexes with bifunctional ligands were prepared and found to be photochromic (reversibly change color) as the meetal migrated between functional groups. (10) Chromium arene complexes with tethered functions groups were synthesized for the preparation photochromic chromium compounds. (11) Manganese complexes with tethered bifunctional ligands were prepared and one was found to undergo ultrafast migration between two functional groups. (12) New polypyridyl cobalt complexes were prepared to demonstrate how structural changes affected the rate of hydrogen evolution. (13) Clofibric acid was found to bind cadmium and mercury ions. Clofibric acid is known to bind to a regulator of metabolism in the liver (a perioxisome proliferator activated receptor).

In addition to research, the new spectrometer is used for academic courses.  NMR spectroscopy is the cornerstone of our Molecular Spectroscopy laboratory course where undergraduates and graduate students learn to acquire and analyze 1D and 2D proton and carbon spectra with the 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. In addition, we are incorporating the spectrometer in our undergraduate organic laboratory. In the past, students were given spectra of pure product they were supposed have prepared in lab. Students already analyze spectra of a purified products in the lecture course, but more importantly this does not provide the student feedback on the results of their own synthesis or purification.  The observation of side products or impurities would allow students to determine mistakes they may have made leading to a better understanding of the chemistry. We typically have 100 undergraduates each fall and winter semester, and there is not enough time to train the students to use the instrument and have them manually acquire spectra.  The 64 position sample changer allows spectra to be recorded overnight and automatically emailed to each student proton and carbon spectra of their own samples.
